bestBHT.bht: The shepherds, having witnessed the birth of Jesus, returned to their flocks, glorifying and praising God. Their songs, perhaps canticles from the Psalms, expressed the overwhelming emotions in their hearts. Through Jesus' circumcision, He was named Savior, symbolizing His purpose to redeem those under the law. This act also represented His pledge to be obedient, even to the point of death on the cross. Just as the shepherds lifted their voices in adoration, may we too be inspired to honor and exalt God for His astonishing grace and the fulfillment of His promises.

Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: theirs was a song too, probably some canticle from the Psalter—meet vehicle for the swelling emotions of their simple hearts."

in this naming of Him 'Saviour,' in the act of circumcising Him, which was a symbolical and bloody removal of the body of sin, we have a tacit intimation that they 'had need'...no ends of His own, but only 'to redeem them that were under the law, that we might receive the adoption of sons.'"
we must regard Him, in His circumcision, as brought under a palpable pledge to be 'obedient unto death, even the death of the cross.'
Albert Barnes: The shepherds returned - To their flocks.
Glorifying ... - Giving honor to God, and celebrating his praises.
John Calvin: Their zeal in glorifying and praising God is an implied reproof of our indolence, or rather of our ingratitude.

If the cradle of Christ had such an effect upon them, as to make them rise from the stable and the manger to heaven, how much more powerful ought the death and resurrection of Christ to be in raising us to God?
For our faith is properly aided by the works of God, when it directs everything to this end, that the truth of God, which was revealed in his word, may be brought out with greater clearness.
Philip Schaff: Lessons from the Nativity: God has in every birth His admirable work. But God to be a child, that is the miracle of miracles.

The great God to be a little babe ; the Ancient of Days to become an infant; the King of eternity to be two or three months old, the Almighty Jehovah to be a weak man; God immeasurably great, whom heaven and earth cannot contain, to be a babe a span long...
Glory and shame, the highest heavens and the lowly manger, angels and shepherds, how much in keeping with the birth of the God-man, God emptying Himself to become man!
John Gill: They glorified God on account of the birth of the Messiah; and praised him, wondering at his grace, and the high honour put upon them."
They praised him, wondering at his grace."
There was such an exact agreement between the things they had seen, and the angel's account of them.
John Wesley: For all the things that they had heard — From Mary; as it was told them - By the angels.

bhtAttempts.bht: The shepherds, in returning to their flocks, glorified and honored God, celebrating His praises. Their joy and gratitude caused them to sing songs, perhaps canticles from the Psalms, expressing their overflowing emotions. In the act of Jesus' circumcision, symbolizing the removal of sin, He was named Savior, signifying His purpose to redeem humanity and bring them into the adoption of sons. His circumcision also foreshadowed His obedience unto death, even on the cross. This miraculous birth of God as a child, the Almighty becoming weak and small, is a wondrous marvel. The shepherds' response of glorifying and praising God rebukes our own lack of enthusiasm and gratitude. If the birth of Christ had such a profound impact on them, how much more should His death and resurrection elevate us to God? Let us be inspired by their example, directing everything towards revealing and magnifying the truth of God in faith.

The shepherds, having witnessed the birth of Jesus, returned to their flocks and glorified God, singing songs filled with awe and gratitude for this miraculous event. Jesus' act of circumcision represented His commitment to be obedient even unto death on the cross. The shepherds' response serves as a reminder of our own need to display zealous praise and honor to God. If the birth of Christ had such a profound impact on them, we should be even more stirred by His death and resurrection. Let us draw inspiration from their example, ensuring that our faith directs everything towards making known the truth of God.

The shepherds, upon witnessing the birth of Jesus, returned to their flocks, glorifying and praising God. Their songs, perhaps canticles from the Psalms, expressed the overwhelming emotions in their hearts. Through Jesus' circumcision, He was named Savior, symbolizing His purpose to redeem those under the law. This act also represented His pledge to be obedient, even to the point of death on the cross. Just as the shepherds lifted their voices in adoration, may we too be inspired to honor and exalt God for His astonishing grace and the fulfillment of His promises.

The shepherds, having witnessed the birth of Jesus, returned to their flocks, glorifying and praising God. Their songs, perhaps canticles from the Psalms, expressed the overwhelming emotions in their hearts. Through Jesus' circumcision, He was named Savior, symbolizing His purpose to redeem those under the law. This act also represented His pledge to be obedient, even to the point of death on the cross. Just as the shepherds lifted their voices in adoration, may we too be inspired to honor and exalt God for His astonishing grace and the fulfillment of His promises.

After witnessing the birth of Jesus, the shepherds returned to their flocks, filled with awe and gratitude for the miraculous event. Singing songs, possibly from the Psalms, they glorified and praised God. Jesus' circumcision symbolized His commitment to be obedient unto death, even the death of the cross, emphasizing His role as the Savior who would redeem those under the law and bring them into adoption as sons. Their exuberant response serves as a reminder for us to offer our own zealous praise and honor to God.
